title: Ningla A-Na [long version]
viewing_guidelines: Aboriginal and Islander viewers should note this work may contain images of deceased people and caution should be exercised when viewing.
subject_group: Economics, Philosophy, Politics, Religion & Sociology/Aboriginal Australians - Government relations

abstract: 'Ningla An'a' documents Aboriginal activism in south-eastern Australia in the 1970s and shows how the activists changed the direction of the movement both nationally and internationally.
description: For the first time in 200 years of white domination, Aboriginal people confronted the government at a national level – and in the words of poet, author and campaigner for Indigenous land rights Roberta "Bobbi" Sykes, achieved "a political victory". Framed within an international human rights context, 'Ningla A-Na' (Hungry for Land) uses television news coverage of the clash between  protesters and police at the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in 1972 to great effect, showing how the event was portrayed both nationally and internationally. Interviews with Dr Fred Hollows, Shirley Smith (Mum Shirl), Bob Maza, Carol Johnson and Paul Coe contextualise the issues advocated by the Black movement. This film gives voice to the most talented and effective Indigenous activists in the country at the time. Source:  Australian Screen
